author: @ryan-tabar
text: # You can turn the process into a decorator so you can add it to any function  def memoization(original_function): Â  Â  cache = {} Â  Â  def inner_function(arg): Â  Â  Â  Â  if arg in cache: Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  print(f"Result was retrieved from cache.") Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  return cache[arg] Â  Â  Â  Â  else: Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  print(f"Memoizing result of function {original_function.__name__}({arg}).") Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  cache[arg] = original_function(arg) Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  return cache[arg] Â  Â  return inner_function   @memoization def square(number): Â  Â  return number ** 2

author: @user-xc5xf8gp8n
text: Summary: Memoization refers to the mechanism that makes a function not having to compute the output using an input, when the function has been executed using the same input before. This is possible because the computer memorizes the input:output pair.   This tool can be demonstrated in python using an if statement and a dictionary outside the function.

author: @pipboy214
text: Maybe your video is good for a first grasp of the term, and you could say thats the point, but memoization is also a technique that doesn't need an external data structure to work, i sugest you to read and maybe talk about it, cause nobody wants dirty globals or spaghetti oriented programming, when You can implement a memoized pure function.
